Fever: Fever does not necessarily need to be treated, and most people with a fever recover without specific medical attention.
Cough: The treatment of a cough in children is based on the underlying cause
Nasal_congestion: humidifier, warm showers, drinking fluids, using a neti pot, using a nasal saline spray, and sleeping with one's head elevated
Rhinorrhea: not necessary since it will clear up on its own
Blood_in_stool: Treatment of bloody stool depends largely on the cause of the bleeding.
Constipation: increased intake of water and fiber (either dietary or as supplements)
Dysphagia: swallowing therapy, dietary changes, feeding tubes, certain medications, and surgery
Palpitations: depend on the severity and cause of the condition
Knee_pain: physical therapy exercises, pain-reducing drugs such as ibuprofen, joint stretching, knee replacement surgery, and weight loss in people who are overweight
Low_back_pain: remaining active, avoiding activity that worsen the pain, and understanding self-care of the symptoms
Paresthesia: immunosuppressant prednisone, intravenous gamma globulin (IVIG), anticonvulsants such as gabapentin or Gabitril and antiviral medication
Rash: steroid topical creams (such as hydrocortisone) or non-steroidal treatments
Pneumonia: Antibiotics by mouth, rest, simple analgesics, and fluids
Delayed_onset_muscle_soreness: any measure that increases blood flow to the muscle, such as low-intensity activity, massage, nerve mobilization, hot baths, or a sauna visit
Back_pain: remain active and return to normal activities
Dry_eye_syndrome: avoidance of exacerbating factors, tear stimulation and supplementation, increasing tear retention, and eyelid cleansing and treatment of eye inflammation.
Sleep_deprivation: implement healthier sleep habits, also known as sleep hygiene
Somnolence: to get plenty of rest and get rid of distractions
Tremor: treating the patient's underlying psychological problem
Chronic_pain: The combined knowledge of various medical professions and allied health professions

Fever: The use of a fan or air conditioning
Shortness_of_breath: active assisted cough techniques, volume augmentation such as breath stacking, education about body position and ventilation patterns and movement strategies to facilitate breathing.
Headache: beta blockers, antidepressants, anticonvulsants and NSAIDs
Vomiting: anticholinergics, antihistamines, dopamine antagonists, serotonin antagonists, and cannabinoids
Diarrhea: Medications such as loperamide (Imodium) and bismuth subsalicylate
Blood_in_stool: vitamins that are important for RBC formation
Constipation: Soluble fiber supplements such as psyllium
Dysphagia: Treatment strategies will differ on a patient to patient basis
Low_back_pain: attempting to return to normal activities as soon as possible within the limits of pain
Neck_pain: medication, body mechanics training, ergonomic reform, and physical therapy
Back_pain: Superficial heat and massage, acupuncture, and spinal manipulation therapy
Heartburn: Medicines such as H2 receptor antagonists or proton pump inhibitors

Cough: A trial of antibiotics or inhaled corticosteroids
Anosmia: steroidal treatment or removal of the polyp
Nasal_congestion: combining nasal sprays with "nasal breathing exercises" (NBE)
Rhinorrhea: saline nasal sprays and vasoconstrictor nasal sprays
Abdominal_pain: "GI cocktail" that includes an antacid (examples include omeprazole, ranitidine, magnesium hydroxide, and calcium chloride) and lidocaine.
Constipation: milk of magnesia or polyethylene glycol
Dysphagia: a supplementary nonoral feeding method of nutrition
Knee_pain: Interventions such as exercises that target both the knee and the hip, foot bracing, and patellar taping
Dry_eye_syndrome: cleaning the eyelids morning and night with mild soaps and warm compresses
Tremor: Surgical intervention such as thalamotomy and deep brain stimulation

Diarrhea: Appropriate amounts of supplemental zinc and potassium
Blood_in_stool: colonoscopy and clipping, surgical intervention, or other measures
Dysphagia: receiving nutrition through a method that bypasses the oropharyngeal swallowing mechanism including a nasogastric tube, gastrostomy, or jejunostomy.
Low_back_pain: superficial heat, massage, acupuncture, or spinal manipulation
Paresthesia: high doses of Baclofen multiple times a day
Dry_eye_syndrome: Wearing glasses or directing gaze downward, for example, by lowering computer screens

Fever: Medications that lower fevers are called antipyretics
Chest_pain: manipulation therapy or chiropractic therapy, acupuncture,  or a recommendation for increased exercise
Palpitations: address the cause of irritation to the vagus nerve or the parasympathetic nervous system generally.
Neck_pain: Motor control using cranio-cervical flexion exercises
Pneumonia: intensive care unit admission for observation and specific treatment

Fever: Using both paracetamol and ibuprofen at the same time or alternating between the two
Chest_pain: A combination therapy of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and manipulation therapy with at-home exercises
Dysphagia: texture modification of foods, thickening fluids and positioning changes during swallowing
Pneumonia: heated humidified high-flow therapy delivered through nasal cannulae, non-invasive ventilation
Back_pain: hemi- or partial- laminectomy or discectomy
Chronic_pain: tricyclic antidepressants, serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, and anticonvulsants

Shortness_of_breath: modifying activities (physical and mental), practicing relaxation techniques, pacing techniques, energy conservation techniques, learning exercises to control breathing, and education
Headache: parenteral (through a needle in the skin) triptans and antiemetics
Blood_in_stool: topical nitrates or calcium channel blockers and surgical interventions for chronic or complex cases
Constipation: physical intervention such as manual disimpaction
Palpitations: Changing body position (e.g. sitting upright rather than lying down)
Xerostomia: intraoral devices and integrated mouthcare systems

Shortness_of_breath: non-pharmacological approaches to treating breathlessness may be combined with medication.
Pneumonia: treated with 30 ml/kg of crystalloid infused intravenously
Tremor: the increase of damping or inertia in the upper limb
Chronic_pain: hormonal medications such as oral contraceptive pills

Headache: relaxation training, electromyographic feedback and cognitive behavioral therapy may be considered for migraine treatment, along with medications.
Dry_eye_syndrome: mild topical steroids or with topical immunosuppressants such as ciclosporin (Restasis)
Chronic_pain: techniques such as trigger point injections, neurolytic blocks, and radiotherapy

Pneumonia: lay on their front for at least 12 hours a day

Chronic_pain: Psychological treatments, including cognitive behavioral therapy and acceptance and commitment therapy

Blood_in_stool: a proton pump inhibitor, with the addition of an H2 blocker
Low_back_pain: Motor control exercise accompanied by manual therapy
Back_pain: surgery may be indicated when a trial of antibiotics is ineffective

Pneumonia: amoxicillin, doxycycline, and in some areas a macrolide (such as azithromycin or erythromycin)
Dry_eye_syndrome: Topical ciclosporin (topical ciclosporin A, tCSA) 0.05% ophthalmic emulsion

Insomnia: The creation of a positive sleep environment

Pneumonia: β-lactam such as cephazolin plus macrolide such as azithromycin

Diarrhea: taking digestive enzymes containing lactase when consuming dairy products
Dry_eye_syndrome: Heating systems that try to unblock the oil glands in the eye
Chronic_pain: health practices or products that are used to treat pain or illness

Low_back_pain: short term use of opioids such as morphine
Pneumonia: third- and fourth-generation cephalosporins, carbapenems, fluoroquinolones, aminoglycosides, and vancomycin

Low_back_pain: antiseizure drugs gabapentin, pregabalin, and topiramate
Facet joint injections and steroid injections into the discs

Pneumonia: The addition of corticosteroids to standard antibiotic treatment
Insomnia: the use of computer based CBT

Low_back_pain: Discectomy (the partial removal of a disc that is causing leg pain)
Pneumonia: adding corticosteroids to the standard PCP pneumonia treatment

Insomnia: over-the-counter antihistamines such as diphenhydramine or doxylamine

Low_back_pain: Chiropractic care or spinal manipulation therapy (SMT)
acute low back pain massage therapy
Capsicum, in the form of either a gel or a plaster cast
Pneumonia: clindamycin, a combination of a beta-lactam antibiotic and metronidazole, or an aminoglycoside

Low_back_pain: Multidisciplinary biopsychosocial rehabilitation (MBR), targeting physical and psychological aspects

Insomnia: Agomelatine, a melatonergic antidepressant with sleep-improving qualities
Nonbenzodiazepine sedative-hypnotic drugs, such as zolpidem, zaleplon, zopiclone, and eszopiclone
Herbs such as valerian, chamomile, lavender, or cannabis
